message.content:
<<<api>>>: InputStream.read
<<<code>>>: 
ProcessBuilder builder = new ProcessBuilder(PROCESS);
builder.redirectErrorStream(true);
Process p = builder.start();

InputStream i = p.getInputStream();
BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(i));
String line;
while ((line = reader.readLine()) != null) {
    System.out.println(line);
}

String command = com.nextLine();
OutputStream o = p.getOutputStream();
o.write(command.getBytes());
o.flush();
// Do not close the OutputStream here
<<<explanation>>>: The InputStream.read() method is blocking, which means it will wait until there is data available to read. If there is no data available, it will simply block and wait. This can cause your program to hang if the process does not produce any output. To solve this, you can use a BufferedReader to read the output line by line. This way, you can process the output as it becomes available. Also, you should not close the OutputStream after writing the command. Closing the OutputStream will signal the end of the input to the process, which might cause it to terminate. Instead, you should flush the OutputStream to ensure that the command is sent to the process.
